title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a firearm as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code defines a firearm as a device that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. Additional sections expand the definition to include rocket launchers and similar devices containing explosive materials. The Penal Code defines a firearm as a device that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. Sections 16750, 16840(b), 25400, 25850-26025, 26030(a)-(c), and 26035-26055 list provisions where an unloaded antique firearm is not considered a firearm. Other sections exempting unloaded antique firearms include 16730(a)(c), 16550, 16960, 17310, 26350-26400, 26500-26588, 26700-26915, 27510, 27530, 27540, and 27545. In Sections 27510 to 27545 and Sections 29010 to 29150, the definition of "firearm" is specified. In certain sections, the term "firearm" excludes destructive devices or includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into a functional firearm. The definition of "frame" and "receiver" in relation to firearms is clarified in this section, specifying that it includes parts that require further machining to be used as a functional weapon. This section also amends Section 16520 of the Penal Code. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel using combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The curr_chunk lists various sections of the Penal Code that include definitions of firearms and related devices, such as rockets and explosive materials. The curr_chunk lists specific sections of the Penal Code that define firearms and exclude unloaded antique firearms in certain provisions. The listed sections of the Penal Code define firearms and exclude certain types of weapons in different provisions. The Penal Code defines "frame" and "receiver" as parts of a firearm housing the firing mechanism and barrel. These parts include blanks or machined bodies that need further work to function as a weapon. Section 16520 is amended accordingly. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections related to firearms, rocket launchers, and explosive devices. The definition of "firearm" is expanded to include rocket launchers and similar devices containing explosive materials. The Penal Code includes sections related to firearms, rocket launchers, and explosive devices. The definition of "firearm" excludes unloaded antique firearms in specific provisions. In the Penal Code, various sections define the term "firearm" in different contexts. For example, in Sections 29010 to 29150, it includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted into functional components. The Penal Code defines "frame" and "receiver" as parts of a firearm housing the firing mechanism and barrel, including blanks or machined bodies designed for further modification. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by explosion or combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections that define and regulate firearms, including rocket launchers and similar devices containing explosive materials. The definition of a "firearm" is expanded to include specific provisions in the code. The Penal Code contains sections that regulate firearms, including specific provisions that exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition of a "firearm." Sections 26700 to 29150 of the Penal Code define various aspects of firearms, including exclusions for certain types of weapons and components. The section defines a "frame" and "receiver" of a firearm as the part that houses the firing mechanism and requires further machining to be functional. Section 1.1 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of Senate Bill 894 and certain conditions being met by January 1, 2017. Section 1.2 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of specific bills and conditions being met by January 1, 2017. Section 1.3 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, dependent on the enactment of certain bills by January 1, 2017. No reimbursement required by this act under the California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
